of that band there is only half an arch broken off
nearly along its central axis at a line which may
be drawn about N25E from the head of Loch <s>point of Slate
in Skye<\s> Maree to Loch Eribol in Sutherland & which
divides the Gneiss of Scotland into two <s>dis<\s> districts
of very unequal size, distinguished by <s>the<\s> different
directions of their foliation. The Gneiss immediately
to the Eastward of the last mentioned line dips about
E15S at angles rarely exceeding 15° or 20°: this
dip gradually encreases as we proceed Eastward
till it reaches the perpendicular on the line just
traced through the middle of Ross-shire, thus
forming half an arch only 20 miles wide at its
southern & nearly 30 miles wide at its
northern extremity of which the western half is entirely wanting. But on the western side
of the line between Loch Eribol & <s>the point of Slate<\s> Loch Maree head
all the Gneiss of the main land & that of the
island of Lewis strikes towards the North West:
thus the axes of elevation of the two districts <s>are<\s> run
nearly at right angles to one another. <s>In<\s> Mr.
Cunningham who has drawn attention to the line
commencing at Loch Eribol as far as it runs
through Sutherland, regarded the Gneiss to the
East of that line as of a more recent formation
than that to the Westward of it, stating that
the Eastern Gneiss often overlies the stratified
Quartz-Rock & Limestone, which never occurs
to the Westward of the line in question*. 
*Geognostical Account of Sutherland pp. 96 to 100.
